answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
The general rule of thumb is that a jurisdiction's call volume will go up somewhere between 25-35%, and in some case like Chicago, where there was tremendous citizen buy-in/demand for the service, it jumped by over 50%.  
As to the other types of contacts, Web self-service forms and smartphone apps are changing the answer to that question daily.  It used to be that a jurisdiction was doing well if they had 5-10% of their contacts come in via the Web, but we're starting to see a shift in those numbers as well.


The general rule of thumb is that a jurisdiction's call volume will go up somewhere between 25-35%, and in some case like Chicago, where there was tremendous citizen buy-in/demand for the service, it jumped by over 50%.  

As to the other types of contacts, Web self-service forms and smartphone apps are changing the answer to that question daily.  It used to be that a jurisdiction was doing well if they had 5-10% of their contacts come in via the Web, but we're starting to see a shift in those numbers as well.

author: Matthew Eng
text:
I'm doing research on 311 and would like to know how your muncipality's call volumes changed in the first full year after implementing 311.  For example, did call volumes remain roughly the same as the last full year prior to implementing the program?  Did calls merely shift from multiple call centers to the 311 operation?  What about changes in the volumes of other types of contacts handled by 311 (e.g., e-mails)?  Thanks for your assistance.
Matthew Eng
City of Seattle
title: Call Volumes Before and After 311
